facts.text: Petition filed as Original Jurisdiction Petition No. 87 of 1957 under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 87 of 1957. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on March 7, 1961 by MUDHOLKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. March 7. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MUDHOLKAR, J.-In this petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution the petitioner companytends

facts.text: Petitioner contends that provisions of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 (XXXI of 1950), particularly s. 2(d) and sub-s. (4) of s. 40 are unconstitutional.

anchor.surface_text: In this petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution the petitioner companytends that the provisions of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950  XXXI of 1950  and in particular those of s. 2  d  and sub-s.  4  of s. 40 are unconstitutional.

facts.text: Custodian of Evacuee Properties passed an order against petitioner under sub-s. (4) of s. 40 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: According to him the effect of the order passed against him by the Custodian of Evacuee Properties under sub-s.  4  of s. 40 of the Act is to take away his property without the authority of law.

facts.text: Petitioner purchased 195-51 acres of land in the former Bhopal State from Babu Rehmatullah on June 23, 1950, for Rs. 3,500.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts may number be stated. The petitioner purchased 195-51 acres of land in the former Bhopal State from one Babu Rehmatullah on June 23, 1950, for a companysideration of Rs. 3,500.

facts.text: Babu Rehmatullah was declared to be an intending evacuee by the Assistant Custodian of Evacuee Property.

anchor.surface_text: Rehmatullah was declared to be an intending evacuee by the Assistant Custodian of Evacuee Property. Eventually he left India for Pakistan on June 20, 1951.

facts.text: Babu Rehmatullah left India for Pakistan on June 20, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually he left India for Pakistan on June 20, 1951. On June 12, 1951, the Assistant Custodian of Evacuee Property issued a numberice to the petitioner

facts.text: On June 12, 1951, Assistant Custodian issued notice to petitioner to show cause why the land purchased from Rehmatullah should not be declared evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: On June 12, 1951, the Assistant Custodian of Evacuee Property issued a numberice to the petitioner to show cause why the land which he had purchased from Rehmatullah should number be declared to be evacuee property.

facts.text: After hearing the petitioner, the property was declared to be evacuee property on August 8, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: After hearing the petitioner the property was declared to be evacuee property on August 8, 1951. The petitioner challenged that order in appeal as well as in revision

facts.text: Petitioner challenged the declaration order in appeal and revision under the Act but was unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner challenged that order in appeal as well as in revision as provided in the Act but was unsuccessful. A writ petition preferred by him before the Judicial Commissioner,

facts.text: Writ petition by petitioner before Judicial Commissioner, Bhopal, dismissed in limine on July 14, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: A writ petition preferred by him before the Judicial Commissioner, Bhopal, was dismissed in limine on July 14, 1954. He has, therefore, companye up to this Court under Art. 32 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Petitioner approached Supreme Court under Article 32 after lower court dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: He has, therefore, companye up to this Court under Art. 32 of the Constitution. The first point pressed before us by Mr. B. D. Sharma, on behalf of the petitioner

facts.text: Petitioner made application to Custodian under s. 40 for confirming the sale in his favour, which was rejected on ground that evacuee did not act in good faith.

anchor.surface_text: The reason for raising the companytention is that an application made by the petitioner to the Custodian under s. 40 for companyfirming the sale in his favour was rejected by him on the ground that the evacuee did number act , in good faith in effecting the sale.

facts.text: Custodian held inquiry under sub-s. (4) of s. 40 and rejected application under clause (a) as transaction not entered into in good faith by evacuee.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-s.  4  of s. 40 P.reads thus The Custodian shall hold an inquiry into the application in the prescribed manner and may reject the application, if the is of opinion that  a  the transaction has number been entered into in good faith

facts.text: Prior to sale to petitioner, Rehmatullah sold a house to some nurses for inadequate consideration, but that sale was confirmed by Custodian.

anchor.surface_text: He said that prior to the sale of the land to him by Rehmatullah, the latter had sold a house to some nurses and that sale was found to be for inadequate companysideration but in spite of that it was companyfirmed by the Custodian

facts.text: Petitioner contends discrimination by Custodian in confirmation of transaction compared to nurses' house sale.

anchor.surface_text: while the sale in his favour, though found to be for an adequate companysideration was number companyfirmed. We would repeat that the order of the Custodian is a judicial order and merely because he may have gone wrong in dealing with one case we cannot hold that the petitioner has been discriminated against.

facts.text: D. Sharma appeared for the petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: D. Sharma, for the petitioner. S. Bindra, R H. Dhebar and T. M. Sen, for the respondents. 1961. March 7.

facts.text: S. Bindra, R H. Dhebar and T. M. Sen appeared for the respondents.

issues.text: whether the provisions of the Evacuee Property Act and particularly those of ss. 2(d) and 40(4) are unconstitutional, because they enable the State to take away property without paying any compensation therefor as required by Art. 31(2) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The first point pressed before us by Mr. B. D. Sharma, on behalf of the petitioner is that the provisions of the Evacuee Property Act and particularly those of ss. 2 (d) and 40 (4) are unconstitutional, because they enable the State to take away property without paying any compensation therefor as required by Art. 31 (2) of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether the protection afforded by Art. 31(5)(b)(iii) is limited to a law which itself declares any property to be evacuee property and not to a law which empowers an authority to declare any property as evacuee property

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sharma, however, contends that the protection afforded by the aforesaid clause must be limited to a law which itself declares any property to be evacuee property and not to a law which empowers an authority to declare any property as evacuee property.

issues.text: whether the property in question is not evacuee property and the provisions of Art. 31(1) of the Constitution are a bar against taking it away, i.e., deprivation without authority of law

anchor.surface_text: What Art. 31 1  prohibits is deprivation of property save by authority of law. No doubt the petitioner can say that he is deprived of his property because of the declaration made by the Custodian that it is evacuee property. But then this declaration has been made in pursuance of a law enacted by Parliament.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual application of Art. 31(5)(b)(iii) exempting evacuee property laws from Art. 31(2) compensation requirement

holdings.text: The words property declared by law to be evacuee property would necessarily include property which companyld be declared as evacuee property. [...] The protection afforded by the companystitutional provision [...] extends to a law which provides for the determination of the criteria for declaring property to be evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot accept the companytention. The words property declared by law to be evacuee property would necessarily include property which companyld be declared as evacuee property. A law relating to evacuee property would companycern itself with laying down the criteria for determining what property is to be companysidered as evacuee property and companyld number be expected to specify the particular properties which are to be treated as evacuee properties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive and textual interpretation of 'property declared by law' includes properties declarable under criteria in law, not just specifically named

holdings.text: What Art. 31 1  prohibits is deprivation of property save by authority of law. [...] this declaration has been made in pursuance of a law enacted by Parliament.

anchor.surface_text: The next argument of learned companynsel is that the property in question is number evacuee property and that the provisions of Art. 31 1  of the Constitution are a bar against taking it away. It is difficult to appreciate the argument. What Art. 31 1  prohibits is deprivation of property save by authority of law.

holdings.text: Apart from the fact that the words good faith occur in a number of statutes and have acquired a definite meaning in companyrts of law, it may be pointed out that the power companyferred by sub-s.  4  of S. 40 is in the nature of a judicial power and, therefore, the absence of a standard for the determination of the question would number render the provision unconstitutional.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the fact that the words good faith occur in a number of statutes and have acquired a definite meaning in companyrts of law, it may be pointed out that the power companyferred by sub-s.  4  of S. 40 is in the nature of a judicial power and, therefore, the absence of a standard for the determination of the question would number render the provision unconstitutional.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Good faith' has established legal meaning; s.40(4) confers judicial power on Custodian, obviating need for exhaustive standards

holdings.text: the order of the Custodian is a judicial order and merely because he may have gone wrong in dealing with one case we cannot hold that the petitioner has been discriminated against.

anchor.surface_text: We would repeat that the order of the Custodian is a judicial order and merely because he may have gone wrong in dealing with one case we cannot hold that the petitioner has been discriminated against.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Custodian exercises judicial power; isolated error in another case does not amount to unconstitutional discrimination

anchor.surface_text: The short answer to this companytention is that the provisions of a law made in pursuance of any agreement entered into between the Government of India and the Government of any other companyntry or otherwise With respect to property declared by law to be evacuee property will number be affected by the provisions of cl. 2 of Art. 31.
